normalised: ## Rental Agreements: Don't Get Caught Off Guard Like Raju!

unnormalised: ## Rental Agreements: Don't Get Caught Off Guard Like Raju!
normalised: Hey folks! Let's talk rental agreements. We all know someone like Raju who got burned because he didn't read his agreement properly. Don't be a Raju! Renting in India, especially in booming cities like Bangalore or Mumbai, can be tricky. A solid rental agreement (or rent agreement as some call it) is your safety net.

unnormalised: Hey folks! Let's talk rental agreements. We all know someone like Raju who got burned because he didn't read his agreement properly. Don't be a Raju! Renting in India, especially in booming cities like Bangalore or Mumbai, can be tricky. A solid rental agreement (or rent agreement as some call it) is your safety net.
normalised: Think of it this way: it's like the spice mix for your biryani during Onam – get it wrong and the whole thing is ruined!

unnormalised: Think of it this way: it's like the spice mix for your biryani during Onam – get it wrong and the whole thing is ruined!
normalised: So, what should you be looking for? First, the basics: who's who (landlord, tenant), property address (obviously!), and the monthly rent. Speaking of rent, make sure it's crystal clear when it's due. Is it the first of every month, or is there a grace period? What about late fees? Get it all in writing.

unnormalised: So, what should you be looking for? First, the basics: who's who (landlord, tenant), property address (obviously!), and the monthly rent. Speaking of rent, make sure it's crystal clear when it's due. Is it the 1st of every month, or is there a grace period? What about late fees? Get it all in writing.
normalised: Then there's the security deposit. Standard is usually two to three months' rent, right? So, if your rent is rupee fifteen thousand, expect a deposit of around rupee thirty thousand to rupee forty five thousand. The agreement should clearly state when and how this deposit will be returned. We’re talking within fifteen days of moving out, or some other pre-agreed timeframe.

unnormalised: Then there's the security deposit. Standard is usually 2-3 months' rent, right? So, if your rent is Rs. 15,000, expect a deposit of around Rs. 30,000 - Rs. 45,000. The agreement should clearly state when and how this deposit will be returned. We’re talking within 15 days of moving out, or some other pre-agreed timeframe.
normalised: Also, pay attention to the lock-in period. Some agreements might say you can't leave before six months or a year. If you break the agreement early, you might lose your deposit. Nobody wants that!

unnormalised: Also, pay attention to the lock-in period. Some agreements might say you can't leave before 6 months or a year. If you break the agreement early, you might lose your deposit. Nobody wants that!
normalised: Maintenance is another biggie. Who's responsible for what? Leaky taps? Broken geysers? Get it spelled out. For example, maybe the landlord covers major repairs, but you're responsible for minor stuff, like replacing a lightbulb.

normalised: And finally, read the fine print! Seriously. Don’t just skim it. If you're unsure about something, ask a lawyer or someone who knows their stuff. Think of it as an investment in your peace of mind. You wouldn't buy a scooter and not read the owner’s manual, would you? It’s the same deal. You don't want to end up walking kilometer to the bus stop because your scooter broke down. Happy renting! And remember, avoid being a Raju!
